posts.name: Ethan Williams
posts.cooked: I want to keep learning new things about frc programming during offseason even though I won’t have a robot during most of it. Any tips or projects that you guys would recommend working on to help?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Sounds like a good time to improve the simulation support of your code.  WPILib provides the tools to do as little or as much simulation as you want when you don’t have a robot to run, but it does require some legwork on the user side to get it working.

posts.name: Gloria
posts.cooked: I am going to spend the majority of my off season looking into historical logging/data visualization software. If you’re interested, and your team doesn’t do much of this, I’d highly recommend looking into it as well. 6328 developed data visualization software called AdvantageScope. A mentor held a conference on it at champs, and it’s worth the watch. Happy programming!

posts.name: Ethan Williams
posts.cooked: Is this conference available online to watch?

posts.name: Ethan Williams
posts.cooked: My team doesn’t do much with the robot until around fall. This kinda means that I won’t be able to do much with it until then.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: Can you talk with your mentors about getting spending more time with the robot? Lots of programming development happens in the offseason, such as vision, odometry, logging, etc. These are all things you can start prepping to do before next season. If you are interested in learning more, then we talk more in this thread about it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
You can see a recording of last year’s Worlds conference presentation on logging already.  That provides a good introduction.

This year we had two conferences, one focused on general logging/AdvantageScope and one focused on log replay/AdvantageKit.  Those presentations haven’t yet been made available but we will do so as soon as we can.  We’re still recovering from World Champs so it may be a little while; thanks for your patience.

Important reminders:

If you’re new to logging you should begin with standard WPILib logging or a well supported alternative like Monologue .  These are the “on-robot” part of the logging solution.

AdvantageScope is a log viewer/data visualization application that is now part of the standard WPILib install - so you already have it available.  It reads and displays data from the logs generated by standard logging frameworks. AdvantageScope is independent of and does not require AdvantageKit!

AdvantageKit is an advanced framework primarily meant to enable log replay .  If you are new to logging, you should not start with AdvantageKit.  It’s a more sophisticated tool that, while powerful, brings a certain degree of complexity and code-structure requirements to enable its functionality.  You should master the basics first before you consider going to this level.

Hope this helps and good luck!

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Many teams have public github repositories, which are great resources for seeing what top teams have done with programming in the past. It’s a great way to learn about good frc programming practices and strategies.

posts.name: Avi
posts.cooked:
I’ve been in a similar situation this offseason. What should I do when I feel like I’ve reached the limit of what I can do in the simulation?

So far we’ve restructured all the code to AKit, created a PoseManager class to store the pose estimator, added pose estimation w/ LL + some basic filtering, learned how to use choreo, and prob some more things I’m forgetting. Everything works in simulation, but I’m concerned about managing all of the new changes when they hit the robot. I also feel like that’s pretty much everything I can work on w/o having the physical robot.
